column1: 10;Deposit - General - Where is the rental deposit regulated?;"The rules about rental deposits are outlined in Section 551 of the German Civil Code (BGB)
column2: under the heading ""Security Deposit for Rent."" Since a rental deposit is a standard security measure that can be agreed upon in any other contract as well
column3: the general provisions of Sections 232 to 240 of the German Civil Code (BGB) also apply."

column1: 11;Deposit - General - What is the purpose of the deposit?;"The deposit serves to protect the landlord's rights. Section 551
column2: paragraph 1
column3: sentence 1 states that the tenant must provide security ""for the fulfillment of their obligations."" This includes all financial obligations and payments by the tenant
column4: such as:

column1: Outstanding rent payments
column2: including advance payments for operating costs.

column1: Additional payments for operating costs.
Costs incurred for repairs due to uncompleted cosmetic repairs.
Claims for damages.
Costs for legal proceedings and litigation.
Compensation for use and damages resulting from delayed move-out."
12;Deposit - General - Do you need to specifically agree to a deposit?;"Yes
column2: you do. The obligation to provide security is not automatically required by the law; it is only limitedly mentioned there (see: How much can the deposit be?). The type and amount of the deposit must be specified in the rental agreement."

column1: 13;Deposit - Amount - How much can the deposit be?;"The deposit cannot exceed three times the monthly base rent. It's important to note that any advance payments for utilities should not be included in this calculation. If the rental includes a lump-sum payment for utilities (known as ""Warmmiete"")
column2: this should be subtracted from the total.

column1: However
column2: there are exceptions where the deposit can be higher:

column1: A third party voluntarily and without request provides an additional deposit
column2: usually to make the tenant more appealing to the landlord.

column1: A specific
column2: particularly expensive
column3: or sensitive item (e.g.
column4: a new hardwood floor) is being exceptionally secured through the deposit.

column1: Existing rental arrears need to be covered to prevent the landlord from rightfully terminating the lease.
The tenant is making the apartment more accessible (e.g.
column2: adding accessibility features)
column3: in which case they must provide additional security to cover the cost of restoring the property to its original condition."

column1: 15;Deposit - Amount - Does the deposit automatically increase with later rent increases? ;"No
column2: the maximum deposit amount is calculated based on the initial base rent.

column1: A later increase of the deposit to three times the new rent is possible
column2: but it requires mutual agreement between the tenant and the landlord for a specific rent increase.

column1: Whether an automatic increase can be stipulated in the rental agreement is a subject of debate. An individually negotiated clause is likely to be valid. However
column2: because the provisions in the rental agreement typically constitute general terms and conditions (AGB)
column3: they must pass AGB review. In most cases
column4: such a clause would be considered surprising and therefore invalid.

column1: In practice
column2: post-rent increase deposit raises are extremely rare."

column1: 16;Deposit - Payment - General - How can the deposit be provided?;"Typically
column2: a savings account or a designated account is created in the tenant's name
column3: but it is pledged to the landlord through a formal declaration or includes a restriction against withdrawal.

column1: Alternatively
column2: the landlord can establish an escrow account
column3: and the tenant transfers the deposit there (referred to as a ""cash deposit"" even though it doesn't involve physical cash).

column1: Another option is a rental guarantee
column2: where other individuals vouch for the tenant's debts."

column1: 17;Deposit - Payment - General - Is the deposit required to be paid before the start of the tenancy?;"No
column2: according to Â§ 551 Abs. 2 BGB (German Civil Code)
column3: at the beginning of the tenancy
column4: only one-third of the deposit is due. The remaining two-thirds are payable with the subsequent rent payments.

column1: However
column2: this provision is seen as a significant shortcoming in the law. A tenant who needs to pay the deposit in installments is often viewed with suspicion by landlords. It's frequently assumed that such a tenant may become financially unreliable at the slightest financial hiccup.

column1: As a result
column2: this provision is rarely relevant in practice
column3: as most tenants voluntarily pay the full deposit before moving in."

column1: 18;Deposit - Payment - General - Can the landlord ask for the deposit in cash?;The landlord cannot ask for the deposit in cash because it would mix with their personal money. Additionally
column2: the deposit must be invested with interest.

column1: 19;Deposit - Payment - General - What can the landlord do if the tenant simply doesn't pay the deposit?;"In such a case
column2: the landlord can and should immediately file a lawsuit to claim the deposit. It's important to note that the payment claim should only be for the three installments (as mentioned earlier)
column3: not for immediate full payment unless the final installment is also due.

column3: non-payment of the deposit is treated the same as non-payment of rent. If the deposit arrears amount to at least two months' worth of base rent
column4: then the landlord can pursue eviction without notice."

column1: 24;Deposit - Payment - Rental Guarantee - Can a guarantee from multiple people be arranged?;"Yes
column2: in such a case
column3: all guarantors are jointly liable

column5: the agreed-upon guarantee amount (up to a maximum of three times the monthly base rent) remains the same
column6: regardless of the number of guarantors.

column1: However
column2: the landlord has the choice of which guarantor to approach for payment. If one guarantor is unable or unwilling to pay in full
column3: the landlord can turn to the next guarantor in line.

In the event of the landlord's insolvency, the deposit would be at risk, and it might not be possible to return it to the tenant at the end of the tenancy. The landlord is required to keep the deposit separate from their personal assets to ensure that their creditors cannot access it.
